title: NY Times - The Lives They Lived
content:
I love the lettering in this piece. Check out each person listed - the lettering is beautiful.

[The Lives They Lived](http://web.archive.org/web/20131015045106/http:/www.nytimes.com/indexes/2008/12/27/magazine/index.html)

Sharon
author: Sharon Van Lieu

comments.content:
yes! Notice under the image: Typeface design by Patrick Griffin/Canada Type.  
It may be Treasury:

[http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/treasury-basic/](http://web.archive.org/web/20131015045106/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/treasury-basic/ "http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/treasury-basic/")

ChrisL

Thanks Chris. I hadn't noticed the attribution.

Sharon

They featured it throughout the interior of the issue as well: large numbers for the table of contents, and [large first names](http://web.archive.org/web/20131015045106/http:/www.nytimes.com/2008/12/28/magazine/28fischer-t.html?_r=1&ref=magazine) for each person who got an article.

Yes, those names are definitely not Treasury. I wonder what they are.

Sharon
It might be something the NYT magazine commissioned for this issue -- i.e., it might not be for sale anywhere.
The Times magazine frequently commissions original fonts.

I was in New York this weekend and saw the issue. It struck me that the lettering succeeded in capturing the idiosyncrasies of those individual lives lived within a common framework, which was the typeface itself combined with our shared understanding of it (e.g. reading). Very moving work.

Interesting to compare it to Shepard Fairey's graphically intensive [cover of Obama](http://web.archive.org/web/20131015045106/http:/www.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,20081229,00.html) for [Time's Person of the Year](http://web.archive.org/web/20131015045106/http:/www.time.com/time/specials/2008/personoftheyear/article/0,31682,1861543_1865068_1867014,00.html), for example. Both aim to capture the spirit of and urgency of individuals but they do so in very different ways.
